content.description: the right-most route on the wave-shaped wall
content.protection: 8 bolts and chains, almost alwayshas fixed draws

content.description:
This a great technical line with wicked thin moves.  If you like difficult face climbing, you will dig this.

This line runs up the recessed vertical portion of the Wicked Crag, between the two giant overhanging features.

Starts up a slab that quickly rears up to a vertical face.  Ultra thin, bouldery moves lead through the first 5 bolts to a height of about 40 feet.The thin section is well-protected and the clips are quite reasonable considering how thin the climbing is.

After the 5th bolt, the climbing eases up, but things remain dicey - 5.11 moves lead up through a 10 foot runout to the 6th bolt.Then 11-/10+ moves lead through similar runouts to the anchor.  The line keeps you engaged and (in my case) pumped all the way to the anchors.
Tough looking start.  May require a cheater stone for shorter folks.
content.location: This route is the furthest one right on the wall you encounter right after you climb down the approach ladder.  Some locals may tell you it's 11d, but I've heard otherwise.

content.description: Tough to just past the 3rd bolt.  Once you hit the undercling/sidepull crack you're good.  Some locals will tell you it's 12b, but the first bolt has the name and grade etched in.
content.location: this route is the second one you come to after you climb down the circus ladder.  It's got a left leaning sidepull start and probably the lowest first bolt in Mill Creek.

content.description: Climb Mossacre through the crux to the jug undercling, continue right to another jug and follow features that lead up and back left to a thin crux.

Start on Scavenger following the rightward-arcing overlap clipping the first three bolts of that route. Diverge up and right from the overlap in a series of powerful and balance intensive moves on overall good holds with generally poor feet. The crux culminates in a tension move and lands on a jug undercling (be wary of the bat). Collect and traverse far left on big holds to finish as for the Sinister.
content.location: On the shady east side of the Wicked Crag.

content.description: Again, do the techno christ crux and encounter multiple cruxes traversing right and up high.
content.location: In between Crushing the Skull and Bowsprit.  Techno Christ crux then traverse to middle line.

content.description: Although this route is often overlooked its actually pretty fun with good stemming up the bottom half until your forced out right onto the face.  The majority of the climb is in the 5.10 range with a distinct crux that may seem hard for the grade if you read it wrong.
content.protection: Bolts to a chain anchor with two large slip hooks
content.location: Same start as Ferns Have Feelings Too, just stay in the corner.

content.description:
This line is beautiful, steep, and probably the best protected route in all of Mill Creek Canyon. The bolts are only 5-6 feet apart - a rarity in Mill Creek.

Flaming Groovy climbs up the center of the big overhanging wave that forms the left side of the Wicked Crag.

The line is flanked on either side by 13s, and often has in-situ draws on it.  It runs up the obvious weakness in the center of the wave.

Starts pretty easy then starts to get steep and increasingly burly.Hits a puzzling crux around the 5th bolt.  Then steep stemming and jamming lead to the anchors.

Great Fun!

A nice, "moderate" route located in the heart of the hardperson's paradise that is the Wicked Crag. Start by making a few stemming moves up a corner. Commit to the face on left via a nice sequence on beautiful, varnished crimps. Work through the distinct crux near the third bolt, and dance your way to the anchors on increasingly easy terrain.

Feel free to post up if you have any FA information or additional beta. Alternatively, if you are offended that I (as a "non-local") posted the route, and wish me to remove it from the database, I can do that too. I just felt it was a shame that no one had posted it yet, given that it is one of the best at the grade in the area.
content.location:
Just right (downstream) of the very steep routes of "The Wave" area at the Wicked Crag. Just left of the beautiful slab testpiece

Techno Christ.

The route climbs a varnished black face with a smooth, wildly overhanging arete on its left.

content.description: The direct start to Crush the Skull. Bust out a v11-ish boulder down low on cool shaped pinches and pockets to link into the headwall on Crush the Skull.

Steep and big holds, a rarity for Mill Creek.. A little spicy at the end, not a rarity for Mill Creek.  Do the first 5 bolts of The Bleeding then traverse left and around corner to finish on Sinister clipping the optional bolt back around the corner.
content.location: Far Left side of Wicked Crag

content.description: Do the first 5 bolts of TechnoChrist then go right, rest on the rail, then work through a powerful crux to the anchors.

On the right side of the Wicked Crag is a large protruding fin of rock.  This route starts under the fin laybacking up a flake to a slab below a roof on the right.  Pull the roof past three bolts, then up a blunt black arete to anchors.  Fun!

This thing is amazing. Great moves. Cool holds. Lots of sidepulls and underclings. The moves get progressively harder, culminating in a powerful stab to a 2 finger pocket pinch.

Would be a perfect route if it wasn't for the small (almost unnoticable) bat-hook hole at the first shake hold.

Bowsprit tackles the huge, overhanging prow of rock that marks the right margin of the Wicked Crag.  Climb up slick rock past a few bolts to a funky underclinging section (making clips by your feet), then turn the corner under the prow via a jug, and crank up the underside of the prow to a cruxy stand-up move off of crimps.

This line starts under an old Eric DeCaria line that, as of time of writing, isn't finished.  The Alt-Right,

alternatively

,

takes a line of small, sharp crimps that goes

right

of the previous project.  The result is another worthy, hard line on the Wicked Crag.  You'll want to bring your crimp, and maybe more importantly skin, A-game for this pitch that offers a lot of crimping on fingernail small, sometimes sharp holds.

Stick clip the first bolt.  A V6 boulder problem off the deck are probably the hardest moves of the route.  Small, tedious feet and hard crimping get you to a rest and second bolt clip.  Caution, though totally safe, the second bolt is a little higher than you'd like it to be.  This is because the boulder problem affords little room for clipping - totally safe with an attentive belayer.  Continue up through the overlapping undercling rail to the 'ghost-match' hole.  From the ghost-match move left and up to a good stance and rest.  Come off the rest to a huge four foot deadpoint to a sloping ledge.  Keep it together and you're clipping the chains on a good stance.
content.protection: Was bolted with intention to stick clip first bolt - 5 bolts total
content.location: Black hangers just left of Scavenger.
